conclusion: Shadows are influenced by the position of the light source relative to the objects and the ground.

In the first image, the light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows (A, B, C, and D) on the ground. The shadows are elongated and positioned behind the objects relative to the light source.
When the light source moves forward, shadows will shift forward (closer to the objects) because the light source is now illuminating the objects from a different angle.
The direction of the shadows will change to align with the new angle of light.
Shadows will become shorter because the light source is closer to being directly above the objects. When the light source is directly above, shadows are minimized in length.
Shadow A (from the decorative object) moves forward and becomes shorter.
Shadow B (from the postcard and stand) moves forward and becomes shorter.
Shadow C (from the vase) moves forward and becomes shorter.
Shadow D (from the bottle) moves forward and becomes shorter.
In the second image, the light source has moved forward, and all shadows (A, B, C, and D) have shifted forward and become shorter compared to the first image.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows (A, B, C, and D) move forward (closer to the objects) and become shorter.
